title: CMS Statistics Questionarie
description:
The present questionnaire has the purpose of informing the Statistics Committee on the details of ongoing analyses, in the interest of a quicker and simpler path to approval of physics results. We recommend that you submit your answers at your earliest convenience, regardless of the status of your analysis (in progress, or in advanced stage, or about to be pre-approved). Changes in the statistical analysis after submission can be sent as a simplified "update", using a link you will receive via email after submitting this form.

Please note: each analysis with a separate CADI entry should fill out a separate entry. It is highly advisable that the questionnaire be filled by an author who knows the details of the full analysis, if necessary in consultation with colleagues.

The purpose of this questionnaire is two-fold:

  • It points you to the relevant best practices and recommendations of the CMS Statistics Committee.
  • It provides the Statistics Committee with feedback about the statistical methods used at an early point of the analysis where potential issues can still be clarified or fixed.

Note: There are multiple-choice answers for many questions. These will not always cover your case. If you are unsure about which answer to choose, just choose the answer you think decribes best what you do and use the text field "Additional comments" for clarification. Also note that many questions foresee that you choose more than one option, in this case choose all which apply.

We thank you for your patience and we encourage you to be as explicative as possible in the free-text boxes. Also, we do appreciate any feedback you may be willing to provide, through a text box at the end.

general.description: Please get familiar with the Statistics Committee TWiki Page, which for example links Frequently Asked Questions, and a Page of Statistics-related References you can cite. You might also want to take a quick look at the Statistics Discussions Hypernews Forum and add the Committee's mailing list cms-statistics-committee@cern.ch to your contacts.

past_interaction.title: Past Interaction
past_interaction.description: Have you interacted with the Statistics Committee in the past (via email, HN, or in person) to discuss an issue with a CMS analysis?

meetings_awareness.title: Open Meetings Awareness
meetings_awareness.description: Are you aware that the Statistics Committee meets regularly (Vidyo only; look for announcement in Statistics Discussions HN forum) and that everybody is welcome to participate?

multivariate.title: Multivariate Discriminants
multivariate.description: Take a second and read the SC TWiki Page on MVA Recommendations.

twiki_read.title: TWiki Read
twiki_read.description: Have you read the TWiki mentioned above?

multi_usage.title: Usage of multi-variante descriminant

type.title: Used Type
type.description: What type of discriminant do you use?

mva_output_usage.title: MVA Output Usage
mva_output_usage.description: How do you make use of the MVA output in the analysis?

output_cut.title: We cut on the output to improve S/B

output_fit.title: We fit the output distribution to get the signal fraction.

input_checks.title: Input Variable Checks
input_checks.description: How have you checked that the input variables, including their dependencies, are well-modeled?

correlation_studies.title: Study of correlalations/dependencies
correlation_studies.description: Do you study the correlations and dependencies between the input variables?

matrix.title: We study the correlation matrix between input variables.

nonlinear.title: We also study dependencies beyond linear correlation (please specify in "Additional comments").

input_selection.title: Input variable selection
input_selection.description: How do you select the input variables? Do you perform any pruning of your initial list of input variables, based on the correlations or dependencies between the input variables?

enum_titles: Yes, we use the correlation matrix and remove highly correlated variables.
No, we keep the complete list.

null_pdf.title: Null PDF
null_pdf.description: Are you aware that some MVA techniques may classify data events as very signal-like if any of their variables take values in regions where the background training samples have no events?

enum_titles: Yes, but this does not apply to my analysis.
Yes, I make training samples large enough and I checked that this does not occur.
Yes, and I need to check whether this applies to my analysis.

background_mix.title: Background Mix
background_mix.description: When training with more than one background, do you mix all samples in the proportions you expect in data?

enum_titles: Yes, but this does not apply to my analysis.
Yes, and I need to check whether this applies to my analysis.

overtraining_checks.title: Overtraining Checks
overtraining_checks.description: How do you make sure you are not affected by overtraining?

enum_titles: We do not perform any checks.
We divide the sample into two subsamples: one used exclusively for training, and the other for all subsequent analysis (optimizations, analysis plots, measurements using the discriminant, etc.).
We do perform checks (please specify in "Additional comments")

robustness_checks.title: Robustness Checks
robustness_checks.description: Do you perform the following robustness check?

enum_titles: We do not perform any checks.

usage.title: Usage of fitting of data distributions
usage.description: Does the analysis include fitting of data distributions? If the answer is "No", please proceed with the next section.

fitting_model_choice.title: Fitting Model Choice
fitting_model_choice.description: How do you choose the fitting model?

test_stats.title: Test Statistic
test_stats.description: Which test statistic are you using to perform the fit(s)?

reason.title: Reason
reason.description: What drove you to this particular choice?

goodness_test.title: Goodness-Of-Fit Test (incl. p-values)
goodness_test.description: Do you perform a goodness-of-fit test for the fit(s)? If i"Yes" or "Undecided", provide additional information and the resultung p-values(s).

toy_exp.title: Check of Pull Distributions in Toy Experiments
toy_exp.description: Do you check that the pull distribution in toy experiments is distributed as expected for an unbiased method (mean 0, width 1)?

enum_titles: No, but we do not use the uncertainty returned by the fit anyway.
Yes, and the result is that the method is unbiased.
Yes, and there are some deviations we account for (please specify in "Additional comments").

cov_matrix.title: Covariance Matrix Check
cov_matrix.description: In case you are using the returned parameters in other parts of your analysis: are you accounting for the covariance matrix (error and off-diagonal correlation terms) of the parameter uncertainties?

enum_titles: Does not apply: We do not use the parameters / uncertainties elsewhere.

bcgrnd_shape.title: Background Shape Choice
bcgrnd_shape.description: In case you perform a fit to the background shape with a function: How do you choose the functional form?

enum_titles: Does not apply: We do not perform this kind of fitting.
We perform robustness checks to show that we are insensitive to the choice of the functional form.
We tried different options and assign a systematic uncertainty from the difference.

fit_func_params.title: Fit Function: Choice of Number of Parameters
fit_func_params.description: In case you perform a fit using a functional form which exists for many different number of parameters (such as polynomials): How are you choosing the number of parameters?

enum_titles: Does not apply: We do not use such a function for fitting.
We choose what looks more or less Ok.
We perform robustness checks to show that we are insensitive to this choice.
We tried different options and chose the most conservative one.
We applied a formal decision procedure (such as Fisher F-Test, LR test, please specify in "Additional comments")

param_bounds.title: Parameter Boundaries
param_bounds.description: Are any of the parameters returned by the fit close (less than 3 sigma) to their physical or pre-defined boundary?

enum_titles: Yes, but we do not use the uncertainty.
Yes, and we check that the error calculation is robust anyway.
Yes, and we trust the errors from the fitter without further checks.

usage.title: Usage of confidence intervals and limits
usage.description: Does the analysis include the setting of limits on some parameter or placing a confidence interval on some parameter? If the answer is "No", please proceed with the next section.

citation.title: Citation of limit or two-sided confidence interval
citation.description: Will you cite a limit or a two-sided confidence interval?

enum_titles: We will only cite a limit.
We will only cite a two-sided interval.
We will decide that after looking at data.
Does not apply: we use a unified interval construction approach (Feldman-Cousins)

atlas_cms_agreement.title: ATLAS-CMS agreement
atlas_cms_agreement.description: Are you aware of the agreement between ATLAS and CMS regarding limit setting?

enum_titles: Does not apply: we do not perform limit computation

support_awareness.title: Awareness of Support by the Statistics Committee
support_awareness.description: Are you aware that the Statistics Committee provides support and a simple recipe to include the derivation of Feldman-Cousins confidence intervals in RooStats jobs that are currently used to compute CLs limits?

enum_titles: Does not apply: we do not perform limit computation

recommendation_awareness.title: Awareness of Recommendation of Prior Sensitivity Analysis
recommendation_awareness.description: If you are using a Bayesian technique, are you aware that the SC recommends to perform a prior sensitivity analysis, both on the PDFs of parameters describing the systematic uncertainties (nuisance parameters) and on the PDF of the parameter to be estimated?

enum_titles: Does not apply: we do not use Bayesian methods

approaches.title: Approach(es)
approaches.description: Mark the approach(es) you are using

bayes_flat.title: Bayesian limits/intervals, with a flat prior for the parameter of interest

byes_ref.title: Bayesian limits/intervals, with a reference prior for the parameter of interest

software.title: Software
software.description: What software tool are you using for your confidence interval calculations?

combine.title: The "combine" tool from the Higgs group

test_stats.title: Test Statistics
test_stats.description: In the case of frequentist/CLs confidence interval construction: which test statistic do you use? If you chose "other", please specify the test statistic used. As an example of the detail you should provide: "the HCG choice is qmu = -2 Ln[L(mu, theta_mu_* )/L(mu* ,theta* )], with 0 < mu* < mu at the denominator, and the numerator has nuisances set at conditional ML estimate for data at given mu, theta_mu_*"

enum_titles: Does not apply: the construction does not make use of a test statistic.
Likelihood ratio in which nuisance parameters and signal cross section are all fixed to a nominal value ("LEP-like").
Profile likelihood ratio in which nuisance parameters are varied in the maximization and the signal cross section parameter is fixed ("Tevatron-like").

Profile likelihood ratio modified for upper limits in which nuisance parameters are varied in the nominator and denominator. The signal cross section mu is fixed to the currently tested point mu* in the nominator and is varied but constrained to 0 <= mu < mu* in the denominator (sometimes called the "LHC-like" test statistic; this is used in the Higgs combination).
Other (please specify in the extra field)

toy_data.title: Toy Data
toy_data.description: In the case toy data is generated as part of the procedureb determine the test statistic distribution or to compute the expected limit / expected limit bandsb the nuisance parameter are chosen for the toys.

enum_titles: Does not apply: the method does not require toys.
Nuisance parameters are sampled from their priors.
A fit to data is performed and the fitted nuisance parameter values are used for toy data generation (this is sometimes called "bootstrapping").

theory_error.title: Theory Error in Signal Cross Section
theory_error.description: In case you convert a limit on a signal cross section into a limit on the mass (or another parameter; we call it "mass" here): how do you account for the theory error on the signal cross section?

enum_titles: Does not apply: we do not cite a limit / only cite a limit on the cross section itself.
We do not account for theory uncertainties.
We vary the theory prediction by one sigma up/down and cite the most conservative limit.
We introduce an additional nuisance parameter in the statistical model which modifies the cross section within the theory uncertainty.
We perform a Bayesian integration over the theory prediction and cite the prior-averaged limit.

discovery.title: Discovery
discovery.description: Take a second a read the TWiki Pages on Search Procedures, Sensitivity Calculations, and Look-Elsewhere Effect (if applicable)?

twiki_read.title: TWiki Pages Read
twiki_read.description: Have you read the discovery-related TWiki pages mentioned above (if applicable)?

Usage.title: Usage
Usage.description: Does the analysis include discovery-related statements, such as citing p-values of the null hypothesis or a "significance"? If the answer is "No", please proceed with the next section.

test_statistics.title: Test Statistics
test_statistics.description: To evaluate the p-value(s) of the null hypothesis, what test statistic was used?

enum_titles: Likelihood ratio in which all nuisance parameters and parameter of interest are fixed to a nominal value
Profile likelihood ratio in which nuisance parameters and parameter of interest are varied in the maximisation

lookelsewhere_effect.title: Look-Elsewhere Effect
lookelsewhere_effect.description: Do you account for the look-elsewhere effect?

enum_titles: Does not apply: we only look for one signal which is completely specified (i.e., mass, width, etc. is known).

unfolding.description: Take a second and read the SC Note on "Interim recommendations on unfolding techniques"

Usage.title: Usage
Usage.description: Is unfolding used in parts of the analysis? If the answer is "No", please proceed with the next section.

bbb_discouragement_awareness.title: Awareness of Discouragement of Bin-By-Bin Folding
bbb_discouragement_awareness.description: Are you aware that the SC discourages the use of bin-by-bin unfolding, or correction factors, and in general on techniques neglecting correlations?

technique.title: Technique
technique.description: Which unfolding technique are you using?

matrix_tikhonov.title: Generalized Matrix inversion with Tikhonov regularization (=SVD by HC6cker and Kartvelishvili / TUnfold)

validation.title: Validation
validation.description: How do you validate the unfolding procedure (e.g., comparison with other techniques, toy studies, etc.)?

event_weight_application.title: Event Weight Application
event_weight_application.description: In case you apply weights to the number of observed (real data) events, e.g. to correct for trigger prescales.

enum_titles: Does not apply: We do not use event weights for data.
We first apply the event weight to get the new (weighted) "observed" spectrum, which is then unfolded.
The unfolding is based on the spectrum built from unweighted events; any weight is handled as part of the smearing matrix.

twiki_read.title: TWiki Pages Read
twiki_read.description: Have you read the SC recommendation TWiki pages on systematic uncertainties?

consideration.title: Consideration of Systematic Uncertainties
consideration.description: Have you considered that systematic uncertainties constrained by sideband measurements in the data, and whose estimate thus depends on the size of the analyzed dataset, should be treated as statistical uncertainties?

recommendations_awareness.title: Awareness of SC recommendations
recommendations_awareness.description: If including a systematic effect as nuisance parameter in the model, are you aware that the SC recommends the use of Gamma or Log-Normal priors instead of truncated Gaussians?

crosschecks.title: Crosschecks
crosschecks.description: Does your analysis include "cross-checks" of your method, e.g. the verification of a technique on a subsidiary set of data? If the answer is "No": Are you deriving a systematic uncertainty on your main measurement from the level of agreement you observe in the cross-check? What would you have done if the cross-check failed (e.g. p-value below 0.01, or other pre-defined criterion)?

enum_titles: Yes, we derive from the level of agreement
No, we do not derive from the level of agreement

failure_procedure.title: Procedure in case of cross-check failure

template_morphing.title: Template Morphing
template_morphing.description: Do you use "template morphing" in you analysis, e.g. to model a systematic uncertainty in the statistical model?

enum_titles: No, we do not perform template morphing.

faq_read.title: FAQ Read
faq_read.description: Did you check if one of the frequently asked questions apply to your analysis?

blind_analysis.title: Blind Analysis Performed
blind_analysis.description: Do you perform a blind analysis? If so, can you succinctly describe what was done?

enum_titles: We do not perform a blind analysis: we didn't see how to do that practically
We do not perform a blind analysis

combined_measurements.title: Methods of Combined Measurements
combined_measurements.description: In case you combine measurements in your analysis: what method is used?

enum_titles: Does not apply: we do not perform a combination

correlation_treatment.title: Correlation Treatment
correlation_treatment.description: In case you use the results of another CMS analysis: how did you treat correlations from common systematic uncertainties and from potential overlap in the datasets?

enum_titles: Yes, this applies (please specify how in "Additional comments")

feedback.title: Comments and Feedback
feedback.description: You're almost there. Just some final questions that may help us to improve our service.

subject_to_change.title: Subjects to Change
subject_to_change.description: What statistical element of your analysis is not yet frozen (what changes can be expected)?

enum_titles: Almost nothing is decided, we still expect major changes.
We already tried some methods but not yet taken a final decision which one to use.
Decision has been taken on methods, but still need some improvements (such as refining an implementation, etc.).

additional_comments.title: Additional Comments
additional_comments.description: Do you have any additional comment related to the analysis? Is there a statistic-related element of your analysis not covered by this questionnaire?

feedback.title: Feedback
feedback.description: Do you have a suggestion for improving this questionnaire? Do you have a suggestion for improving interaction with the CMS Statistics Committee in general or documentation of statistical recommendations?
